questions.question: What is the embryonic origin of the lens?
Where are the youngest fibers of the lens present?
questions.explanation: The youngest fibers of the lens are the peripheral part, the cortex.The nucleus of the lens is the central part containing the oldest fibers.The lens fibers are produced by mitosis of the epithelial cells in the pre-equatorial zone. As thelens fibers elongate and the new ones are formed, the older ones are pushed towards the depth ofthe lens so that the youngest fibers are the most superficially located.268Structure of the crystalline lensAnterior capsule.Anterior epithelium.NucleusCortexAdultInfantileFetalEmbryonicMARIOMARROW

questions.question: At a routine ophthalmological check-up, a patient was found to have bilateral, Y-shaped lensopacities as shown below. He was diagnosed with suture cataracts. Which zone of the lensnucleus is not involved here?258AD
questions.explanation: The primary fibers in the embryonic nucleus of the lens do not form Y-shaped sutures.The image shows bilateral cataracts in the Y-shaped sutures of the lens. These are very slowlyprogressive congenital cataracts and do not require any surgical intervention.•Types of lens nucleus and their age of development:Embryonic nucleus: Innermost nucleus formed at around 1-3 months of gestation•Fetal nucleus: From 3 months of gestation till birth•• Infantile nucleus: From birth to puberty• Adult nucleusAs lens fibers grow anteriorly and posteriorly, a pattern emerges where the ends of the fibersmeet. These patterns of cell association are known as sutures.Y-shaped sutures are recognizable at about 8 weeks of gestation.269Fibres and Sutures of the LensMAAnterior lensepitheliumAnteriorY suture(erect)CortexOMARROWEmbryonalnucleus(not involvedin sutures)PosteriorY suture(inverted)Fetal nucleus

questions.question: What is the ligament of Weigert?

options.A: Attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens
options.D: Attachment of the lens to the ciliary muscles

questions.explanation: The hyaloideo-capsular ligament of Weigert is the attachment of the vitreous to the posteriorcapsule of the lens.It is the annular region (1–2 mm in width and 8–9 mm in diameter) where the vitreous is attachedto the posterior aspect of the lens.Erggelet's or Berger's space is at the centre of the hyaloideo-capsular ligament, a potential spacebetween the vitreous and the lens. The canal of Cloquet arises from this space and coursesposteriorly through the central vitreous, which is the former site of the hyaloid artery in theembryonic vitreous.Posteriorly, Cloquet's canal opens into a funnel-shaped region anterior to the optic disc, whch isknown as the area of Martegiani.Posterior Chamber of EyeCloquet's canalSpace of MartegianiOMARROW270Berger's spaceWeigert'sligamentVitreousbase

questions.question: Where does the crystalline lens derive its nutrition from?
questions.explanation: The crystalline lens derives its nutrition from the aqueous humor.The lens is an avascular structure. It receives nutrition mostly from the aqueous humor and, tosome extent, from the vitreous humor as well. Glucose is the main energy source. Major intrinsicprotein 26 (MIP 26)/Aquaporin o in the lens is responsible for maintaining transparency bytransporting water and glycerol across the lens.Anti-oxidant mechanisms in the lens:•Reduced glutathione (most important)• Glutathione peroxidase• Superoxide dismutase• Catalase.• Vitamin C, Vitamin E, carotenoids.

questions.question: While studying the histological anatomy of the lens, you are measuring the thickness of thelens capsule in various areas. At which of the following zones would you get the lowestmeasurement?
questions.explanation: The lens capsule is the thinnest at the posterior pole, measuring 4 μm.Other options:Option A: At the anterior pole, the thickness of lens capsule is 14 μm.Option C: In the pre-equator region, lens capsule is the thickest, measuring 23 μm.Option D: At the equator, as shown in the illustration below, the thickness is 17 µm.Thickness of the lens capsuleAnterior poleEquator 17 μm-14 μm21 μm21 μm23 μm(thickest)4 μmOMARROW23 μm(thickest)-17 μmEquator271

questions.question: You are observing the given slide in a histology examination. Where is the marked structureabsent?
questions.explanation: The slide shows the histology of the lens and the structure marked in the subcapsularepithelium. The epithelium of the lens is absent on its posterior surface.The lens epithelium is a single layer of cells on the anterior surface of the lens. There is noepithelium on the posterior surface, as these cells are used up in filling the central cavity of thelens vesicle during the development of the lens. The anterior epithelial lining creates new lensfibers throughout a person's life.OMARROWSubcapsularepithelium

questions.question: Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced state by260
questions.explanation: Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced, functional stateby glutathione.Glutathione is present in high concentrations in the lens, particularly in the epithelial layer. Oneof its key functions is to maintain protein thiols in their reduced state, which preserves the lenstransparency by preventing the formation of high molecular weight crystalline aggregates andprotects the lens from oxidative stress.The lens is highly prone to photochemical reactions from continuous exposure to ultraviolet rays(295–400 nm), leading to reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation. Its defence relies heavily onsuperoxide dismutase, ascorbate, catalase and glutathione peroxidase.With ageing or cataracts, levels of glutathione and ascorbic acid (in reduced form) significantlydecrease.

questions.question: As part of a public health initiative, screening for cataract is being carried out. What is themost common cause of this healthcare issue in the population?
questions.explanation: 272The most common cause of cataracts is ageing, specifically senile (age-related) cataract.Important causes of cataract:•••Aging (Most common)Congenital cataract (crystallin gene - CRYAA, CRYAB, CRYGC, CRYGS) (Option A)• Diabetes mellitus (Option B)• Syndermatotic- atopic dermatitis is the most common skin condition associated with cataract• Galactosemia- reversible cataract•Radiation- UV rays, X-rays, gamma rays, infrared•Toxic agents- Corticosteroids, miotics (long-acting anticholinesterases, e.g., echothiophate)(Option C).ObesitySenile cataract is the most common type of acquired cataract and is also known as age-relatedcataract. The two types of senile cataracts are cortical (soft cataract)-75% and nuclear (hardcataract)-25%. In cortical cataract, the cuneiform type (70%) is the most common, and thecupuliform type is the most visually handicapping.

questions.question: You are compiling a literature review on congenital cataracts diagnosed in the last few years.Which of the following is the most common type?
questions.explanation: The most common type of congenital cataract is the blue-dot cataract.Cataracta-punctata-caerulea, commonly known as blue dot cataract, is a prevalent type ofcongenital cataract. It typically develops during the first two decades of life. This condition ischaracterized by distinctive rounded bluish opacities located in the peripheral region of theadolescent nucleus and the deeper cortical layers of the lens. While these opacities are generallystationary and do not impair vision, larger ones may cause slight visual disturbance.

questions.question: The parents of a child have been informed at a PTA meeting that he has a lot of incompleteclasswork. On being questioned, the child complains that he is unable to see things clearlyand is having difficulty in reading and writing. On ophthalmic examination, he is found tohave a cataract. Which type of congenital cataract most commonly presents with thesefindings?
questions.explanation: Lamellar or zonular cataract is the most common type of congenital cataract presenting withvisual impairment.The etiology may be either genetic or environmental in origin.• Genetic- familial autosomal-dominant• Environmental form is associated with:• Vitamin D deficiency.HypocalcemiaSometimes, maternal rubella infection contracted between the 7th and 8th week of gestationmay also cause lamellar cataract.The main mass of the lens internal and external to the zone of cataract is clear.273Small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel (riders) may be seen towards the equator.Slit LightDiffusion Light

questions.question: A 33-year-old woman delivers a baby girl with a congenital rash, as shown below, and patentductus arteriosus. What type of cataract is commonly associated with this condition?DAILY ROUNDS
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario showing blueberry muffin rash, combined with patent ductus arteriosus in ababy girl, suggests a diagnosis of congenital rubella syndrome, which is typically associated with aprogressive, pearly white nuclear cataract.Ocular effects of rubella:• Microphthalmia• Rubella keratitisAngle-closure glaucoma• Nuclear pearly cataract•Salt and pepper fundus (a most common ocular feature of rubella) due to diffuse chorioretinitis.

questions.question: The following finding is found on the ophthalmologic examination of an 18-year-old girl.What is the most likely diagnosis?262
questions.explanation: The image above characteristically depicts a Christmas tree cataract, featuring multiple refractilecolors commonly observed in myotonic dystrophy.Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by difficulty relaxingskeletal muscles after contraction. The initial symptoms typically manifest during adolescence orearly adulthood.Cataracts are an early and prominent feature in 90% of patients with myotonic dystrophy. Theytypically present as fine, dust-like opacities interspersed with iridescent, polychromatic spots inthe cortical layer beneath the anterior and posterior lens capsule, resembling a Christmas tree.These cataracts may remain stable or progress.274Surgical outcomes are generally favourable.

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology OPD with the findings shown below. Shehas been diagnosed with a right-sided senile cataract. Identify the stage of the cataract.
questions.explanation: The above image represents an advanced stage of cataract progression characteristic of aMorgagnian hyper-mature cataract.Morgagnian hyper-mature cataracts are characterized by liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lensis converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, itsposition altering with a change in the position of the head.Senile cataract is the most common type of acquired cataract and is also known as age-relatedcataract. The two types of senile cataracts are cortical (soft cataract)-75% and nuclear (hardcataract)-25%.Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.Nuclear cataracts: These may be pigmented due to the deposition of urochrome pigments. Theseare cataracta brunescens (brown), cataracta nigra (black), cataracta rubra (red).Cuneiform (70%)Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrallyLate visual lossPosterior subcapsular/Cupuliform(5%)Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex justbelow the capsuleEarly loss of visual acuity; most visually handicapping senile cataract

questions.question: Where is polychromatic luster noted?
questions.explanation: Polychromatic luster is seen in complicated cataracts.Due to disturbances in nutrition of the lens due to inflammatory/degenerative disease of otherparts of the eye like iridocyclitis and ciliary body tumors. In inflammations/degenerationsaffecting the posterior segment, a characteristic opacification is seen in the posterior part of thecortex in the axial region (posterior subcapsular cataract).These cataracts present with a breadcrumb appearance and polychromatic luster. Even in theearly stages, vision is impaired.

questions.question: Who among the following patients can potentially develop drug-induced cataracts?
questions.explanation: Patients taking dexamethasone (corticosteroid) are prone to drug-induced cataracts,predominantly presenting as discoid posterior subcapsular cataracts.275Drugs causing cataracts:Other options:Option A: Zoledronate, a bisphosphonate drug can cause orbital inflammation, uveitis, andscleritis.Option B: Hydroxychloroquine, a drug used in malaria and rheumatoid arthritis, does not causecataracts, chloroquine does. It can rarely cause retinal toxicity.Option D: Ethambutol is used in anti-tubercular therapy and its use has been shown to cause opticneuritis.DrugsCorticosteroidsAnticholinesteraseSChlorpromazineType of cataractDiscoid, posterior subcapsularAnterior subcapsularYellow-brown anterior capsular granules/stellate/anterior polarPosterior subcapsularBusulfanChloroquineWhite, flaky, posterior subcapsularAmiodaroneAnterior subcapsular

questions.question: The ophthalmologic examination on a 23-year-old college student revealed the followingimage. What disease is commonly associated with this ocular finding?264
questions.explanation: The given picture of a slit-lamp biomicroscope examination depicts the anterior lenticonus, whichis associated with Alport syndrome.In Alport's syndrome, both anterior and posterior lenticonus are seen, but anterior lenticonus ismore common. The diagnosis of lenticonus is typically confirmed through slit-lamp examination.Note: Lowe's syndrome is an oculo-cerebro-renal syndrome characterized by congenital cataract,glaucoma, and posterior lenticonus

questions.question: A 60-year-old man, diagnosed with bilateral cataracts two months ago, reports being able toread better without prescription glasses. However, he complains that his distant vision hasbecome blurrier. Which type of cataract typically causes this phenomenon?
questions.explanation: The phenomenon described is the second sight of old age, seen in nuclear cataracts.Due to nuclear sclerosis, there is an increase in the refractive index, causing progressive myopia.A patient with presbyopia may be able to read again, without the aid of spectacles. Thisimprovement in vision is termed second sight.276

questions.question: A 38-year-old lady is a known case of diabetes and is on insulin for the last 8years. Hersugars are poorly controlled and now she complains of hazy vision. What type of cataract willbe characteristically noted in her eyes?
questions.explanation: The typical appearance of a diabetic cataract is a snowflake cataract.Hyperglycemia is reflected in a high level of glucose in the aqueous humor, which diffuses into thelens. Here, glucose is metabolized into sorbitol, which accumulates within the lens, resulting insecondary osmotic overhydration.DAILY ROUNDS

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with an inability to see objects in bright light. On examination,she is diagnosed with a cataract. In which of the following cataract is this characteristicfinding not seen?
questions.explanation: The inability to see objects in bright light is not a feature of cuneiform cataract, as the lens opacityis peripheral, allowing visibility in bright light during miosis.The loss of the ability to see objects in bright light is a feature of posterior subcapsular cataract(visually handicapping), cupuliform cataract and nuclear cataract as these present with centralopacities.When a person is exposed to bright light, the pupil undergoes miosis (constriction). These centralopacities come to lie directly in the path of axial rays, allowing no transmission of rays. Therefore,there is an inability to see objects in bright light. However, in dim light, when there is mydriasis(dilatation of the pupil), some rays may pass around the opacity, leading to an improvement indim-light vision.Furthermore, the complicated cataract, steroid-induced cataract, radiation-induced mainlypresent with a posterior subcapsular cataract and therefore have a similar clinical picture.

questions.question: You are counseling the parents of Nisha, a 1-month-old child diagnosed with a congenitallamellar cataract in both eyes. What is the course of treatment you would advise?

options.C: Cataract surgery with intraocular lens (IOL) implant
options.D: Pars plana lensectomy with no IOL implant

questions.explanation: Cataract surgery with an intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is the treatment of choice incongenital cataracts.277It involves an extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with primary posterior capsulorhexis andanterior vitrectomy. After removal of the cataractous lens, a posterior chamber intraocular lens(PCIOL) is implanted.The critical period for the development of the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visualdeprivation disorders is 2-4 months of age. Thus, any cataract dense enough to impair visionmust be dealt with before this age, and the earliest possible time is preferred.•Bilateral dense cataract- early surgery by 4-6 weeks of age• Unilateral dense cataract or involving visual axis- urgent surgery within daysIntracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is contraindicated in children.

questions.question: A 28-year-old girl is being evaluated for an aortic root aneurysm. She says her mother died ofan aortic dissection at the age of 43. She is tall and slim. A musculoskeletal system finding isshown below. What is the most common lens subluxation noted in the genetic disease she issuffering from?266
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette of a girl with tall, slim stature, an aortic arch aneurysm, Steinberg sign(positive thumb sign), and similar family history suggest a diagnosis of Marfan's syndrome. It ismost commonly associated with a superotemporal subluxation of the lens.The image below shows a subluxated lens in a patient with Marfan's syndrome.Congenital subluxation of the lens is called ectopia lentis.Types of ectopia lentis are as follows:•Simple type• Ectopia lentis et pupillae (pupil also displaced in opposite direction)• Ectopia lentis associated with syndromes• Marfan's syndrome- superotemporal subluxation of lens• Homocystinuria- inferonasal subluxation of the lens•Weill-Marchesani- downward, forward subluxation of the lens.278•⚫ Ehler-Danlos syndrome

questions.question: Which of the following diseases does not show a specific pattern of cataract?
questions.explanation: A specific pattern of cataract is not seen in leprosy.A specific pattern of cararact is seen in the following:•Juvenile diabetes: Snowflake cataract• Myotonic dystrophy: Christmas tree cataract• Wilson's disease: Sunflower cataract279
